title: Failed Run Capacitor
description: The outdoor unit hums but neither the compressor nor condenser fan starts. The customer reports the system was working yesterday but stopped cooling this morning.
symptoms: Outdoor unit hums but doesn't start

faults.description: Run capacitor has failed - shows significantly reduced capacitance

diagnosticSteps.action: Measure voltage at power supply L1 to L2
diagnosticSteps.hint: Always start by confirming power is present

diagnosticSteps.action: Verify voltage at contactor coil terminals
diagnosticSteps.expectedResult: Should read ~24V AC when thermostat calls
diagnosticSteps.hint: If no 24V, the thermostat or transformer may be the issue

diagnosticSteps.action: Measure voltage at contactor output terminals
diagnosticSteps.expectedResult: Should read ~240V when contactor is pulled in
diagnosticSteps.hint: No voltage means contactor contacts may be bad

diagnosticSteps.action: Turn off power, discharge capacitor, measure capacitance
diagnosticSteps.expectedResult: HERM side should be ~45µF, FAN side should be ~5µF
diagnosticSteps.hint: A weak or failed capacitor is a common cause of this symptom

diagnosticSteps.action: With power off, measure resistance between C-R, C-S, and R-S
diagnosticSteps.expectedResult: All readings should be low ohms, R-S should equal C-R + C-S
diagnosticSteps.hint: Open or shorted windings indicate compressor failure

learningObjectives: Identify symptoms of a failed run capacitor
Properly discharge a capacitor before testing
Use a multimeter to measure capacitance
Understand the relationship between capacitor failure and motor starting issues
